description: From the perfect passive participle stem of Latin concatēnāre (“to link or chain together”), from con- (“with”) + catēnō (“chain, bind”), from catēna (“a chain”).

entries.meaning: (biology) Joined together as if in a chain.
examples: The Nostocoid type consists of small rounded blue-green cells not over 5p. in diameter and arranged in chains which are often much broken up in the cephalodium, so that the concatenate arrangement is hardly apparent.

verbs.description: concatenate (third-person singular simple present concatenates, present participle concatenating, simple past and past participle concatenated)

entries.meaning: To join or link together, as though in a chain.
examples: Locke, by contrast, contended that [madness] was essentially a question of intellectual delusion, the capture of the mind by false ideas concatenated into a logical system of unreality.
